name: inflame
content:
inflame verb [T or I]
(CAUSE STRONG FEELINGS)
Add to word list
Add to word list
to cause or increase very strong feelings such as anger or excitement: Reducing the number of staff is certain to inflame the already angry medical profession.inflame passions Pictures of the bombed and burning city inflamed passions further. The image was used to inflame rather than instruct or reveal truth.
More examplesFewer examplesYou can understand how he inflames these kinds of passions.Going in guns blazing just inflames these situations.It will also serve to act as a check against using comments and phrases that inflame rather than educate.

inflame verb [T or I]
(MAKE SWOLLEN)
to make a part of the body become red, painful, and swollen; to become red, painful, and swollen: Asthma is a chronic condition that inflames the inside walls of the airways. It triggers antibodies which cause the lining of the gut to inflame, causing abdominal pain.
More examplesFewer examplesAcid can enter the lungs and inflame them, causing a secondary pneumonia.Inflaming a knee while putting out the rubbish - that has to be the most ridiculous football injury of all time.Blister agents attack body tissues, blistering the skin and inflaming the eyes.Ozone and other chemicals in smog further inflame the airway linings in people with respiratory diseases.
